qas.question: What theory was developed by Arnold?
Who published What Is An Emotion?: Classic and Contemporary Readings?
What theory wasn't developed by Arnold?
Who published What Isn't An Emotion?: Classic and Contemporary Readings?

context: Some of the most influential theorists on emotion from the 20th century have died in the last decade. They include Magda B. Arnold (1903–2002), an American psychologist who developed <a0_0>the <b5_0>appraisal theory of emotions<b5_0/><a0_0/>; Richard Lazarus (<b6_0>1922<b6_0/>–<a1_0>2002<a1_0/>), an American psychologist who specialized in emotion and stress, especially in relation to cognition; Herbert A. Simon (1916–2001), who included emotions into decision making and artificial intelligence; Robert Plutchik (1928–2006), an American psychologist who developed a psychoevolutionary theory of emotion; Robert Zajonc (1923–2008) a Polish–American social psychologist who specialized in social and cognitive processes such as social facilitation; <a2_0><b7_0>Robert C. Solomon<b7_0/><a2_0/> (1942–2007), an American philosopher who contributed to the theories on the philosophy of emotions with books such as What Is An Emotion?: Classic and Contemporary Readings (<a3_0><b8_0>Oxford<b8_0/><a3_0/>, 2003); Peter Goldie (1946–2011), a British philosopher who specialized in ethics, aesthetics, emotion, mood and character; Nico Frijda (1927–2015), a <a4_0>Dutch<a4_0/> psychologist who advanced the theory that human emotions serve to promote a tendency to undertake actions that are appropriate in the circumstances, detailed in his book The Emotions (1986).
